story.title: 11:30 am, Friday, 02/02
story.text:
Good morning on this Ground Hog’s Day, Epidemiology Team. Thank you for taking the time to be here. As you know I am Jennifer Shuford, the Commissioner of the Texas Department of Health and Human Services.
We've just received an urgent report of a rapidly unfolding public health crisis and I need your help. We have a cluster of critically ill patients, and we may have an outbreak, but we are not sure.  I need your investigative skills to help sort through this.  The situation is escalating quickly, the governor wants answers now and CNN is calling me. I am getting reports from many regions and cases are climbing, and we need answers—now! The clock is ticking, and lives are at stake, we do not have much time.
That's why we're calling on you, our brightest and most talented epidemiology team, to step into action. Your mission: determine if there is an outbreak and if so investigate the source, define the cases, identify the agent, and recommend containment strategies so we can protect our public.  We need to stop this situation in its tracks.
You have limited time, the needed critical resources, and only your expertise to guide you. The health of Texans depends on you. We’re counting on you to solve the mystery and provide me with guidance needed to implement any measures needed to protect the public.
Thank you and good luck—get to work.

puzzles.title: 12:00 pm, Friday, 02/02
puzzles.text:
As a budding outbreak investigator, ready to unravel the mystery, you know that outbreak investigation is like solving a complex puzzle and each piece represents a critical clue.
You will need to navigate through layers of deception, forgotten clues, unexpected twists, and time-sensitive decisions, short tempers, emotions and potential legal issues. Make sure you have your ID, your passport, your field notebook, mask and hand sanitizer.
hints: It's the right ingredients, but in the wrong order!-Sheldon Cooper

puzzles.title: 07:00 am, Saturday, 02/03
puzzles.text:
As you organize your thoughts, the pieces of the mystery start to align.
It's 7 a.m. As the aroma of your morning coffee lingers, you scan the newspaper for clues.
Headlines blur past—nothing groundbreaking yet. But then, your eyes land on this poignant cartoon.
Intrigued, you wonder what else is worth reading in the newspaper.
hints: A boisterous clown does every foolish game: hurling icicles, juggling kaleidoscopes, laughing maniacally, neglecting old pants, quickly revealing sparkling tight underwear, vamping while x-raying your zebra.

puzzles.title: 11:00 am, Saturday, 02/03
puzzles.text: After reading your favorite section of the newspaper, you sit back, satisfied, but still curious. What is happening to all those people? It's all so mysterious. But you know from your training that it's important to talk to them to start piecing clues together. Then, suddenly you get a phone call from an intensivist at one of the teaching hospitals in town. To take the call you connect to Interview1.mp4. You hang up the phone and speak with Dr. Cardigan who gives you a similar story and says that the patient reported eating at XXXXX 4 hours before symptoms started. The patient is now comatose so you call the wife Interview2.mp4. You have now identified 18 individuals who ate with the second case. After interviewing the cases, developing a case definition, what should you send Dr. Shuford?

puzzles.title: BREAKING NEWS: CNN is BREATHING DOWN YOUR BACK. THE REPORTER WAS AT A COCKTAIL PARTY AND HEARD ABOUT THESE CRITICALLY ILL PATIENTS?
puzzles.text: You are meanwhile tracking down some of the individuals who ate with the second case. Reported symptoms include—nausea, dizziness, and memory loss (which, for the record, is NOT a good excuse for forgetting your outbreak skills). You speak with some of the individuals and find out Interview.mp4. You also get some additional critical information.

puzzles.title: Food Inspector's Report
puzzles.text:
Once you piece together that the mussels were the culprit, you waste no time informing the authorities. They respond swiftly, and soon you’re on your way to the restaurant at the heart of the outbreak. When you arrive, the scene is tense—officers are combing through the kitchen, inspecting storage areas, and questioning staff.
Between [Date XXXX] and [Date XXXX], XXX individuals have presented with a mysterious illness of unknown origin. Affected individuals have reported a range of gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea and vomiting, as well as neurological manifestations such as memory loss and dizziness. Preliminary epidemiological investigations suggest a possible link to a local restaurant, where a number of affected individuals dined prior to symptom onset. Of the XXXX patrons who ate at the establishment during the exposure period, XXXX remained asymptomatic, while the remainder developed illness. Further analysis is required to determine how dangerous this outbreak is and identify potential sources of contamination. Investigators are urged to analyze the provided data and calculate key epidemiologic measures to guide the ongoing outbreak response.

puzzles.title: Discovery
puzzles.text:
Now that you've done your field calculations, you are beginning to realize the magnitude of this problem. These numbers represent real people who are getting sick.
One officer approaches you with an odd discovery found in the restaurant owner's office: an almost blank note with only the code XXXX written at the top. "We think it’s more than it seems. The owner must not be around much. The office is empty with only a desk and a shredder. By the way, when we left, the office door locked behind us," they say, handing it over.
Where do you go next?

puzzles.title: What's behind door number ...?
puzzles.text: You head to the office, searching for the shredder, but it’s locked tight. Frustration bubbles up, because you know the answer is behind this office door. But you remember that the owner is terrible with numbers. If she has set a code, she would’ve written it down somewhere she looks at every day.

puzzles.title: Shredder
puzzles.text:
You punch in the code from the menu, and with a satisfying click, the office door swings open. Inside, the shredder sits ominously on the desk, its metallic surface glinting under the dim light. But your excitement is short-lived—a padlock secures the shredder, taunting you. Through the transparent bin, you can see shredded paper teasing you with its potential secrets.
Your mind races. What could the code be?
hints: Your thought drifts to Dr. Shuford's package.

puzzles.title: Location, Location, Location
puzzles.text:
This is one of those fancy locks that requires two-codes. Here's the second half to unlock the padlock and reveal what's inside. Hopefully bringing us one step closer to solving this thing.
You steady your hand and input it into the padlock. A soft click echoes through the quiet office as the lock releases. You lift the shredder lid, revealing the vendor list among the shredded scraps. Relief washes over you as you gently pull the intact document out, its faintly creased surface hinting at its recent handling.
Scanning the list, you recognize familiar names. This is it!

puzzles.title: Budding chemist
puzzles.text:
Arriving at Prince Edward Island, you’re greeted by the serene beauty of the mussel farm, a sharp contrast to the mystery that brought you here. With careful precision, you collect water samples from the farm, paying attention to the areas closest to where the mussels were harvested. The samples are sealed and transported back to a makeshift lab you’ve set up nearby.
Sitting down, you begin your analysis, focusing on the chemical properties of the water.
